## Exercises

### Exercise 1 {-}

Load (or maybe install first) the package `languageR`. Then, load the data set
`quasif` from this package. You can use `?quasif` to inspect the data set.


* Use the function `xtabs()` to inspect the structure of your data. Are your
  factors crossed or nested?

* Create a box plot looking at the distribution of reaction time for short and
  long SOAs

* Visualize your data points individually for each subject. Use `xyplot()` from
  the `lattice` package or functions from the package `ggplot2`

    \item Fit a model with random intercepts for Items and random
      intercepts as well as slopes for Subjects.
    \item Test your random effects using likelihood-ratio tests.

    \item Decide which model fits the data (empirically) best. Compute
      confidence intervals for the estimated parameters of this model.
    \item Look at the model assumptions for this model.

```{r ex04, results = "hide", class.source = "fold-hide", fig.show = "hide"}

library(languageR)
library(lattice)

# load data set
data(quasif)

plot(RT ~ SOA, data = quasif)

xtabs( ~ SOA + Item, data = quasif)
xtabs(~ Subject + Item + SOA, data = quasif)

xyplot(RT ~ SOA | Subject, data = quasif, groups = Item, auto.key = TRUE)

lme1 <- lmer(RT ~ SOA + (1 | Item) + (SOA | Subject),
             data = quasif, REML = FALSE)
summary(lme1)

lme2 <- lmer(RT ~ SOA + (1 | Item) + (1 | Subject) + (1 | Subject:SOA), data = quasif, REML = FALSE)
lme3 <- lmer(RT ~ SOA + (1 | Item) + (1 | Subject), data = quasif, REML = FALSE)
lme4 <- lmer(RT ~ SOA + (1 | Subject), data = quasif, REML = FALSE)

anova(lme4, lme3, lme2, lme1)

confint(lme2, method="boot")

plot(lme2)

qqmath(resid(lme2))
```
